Fig. 1 Diffractogram (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5419 Å) taken for TiO2 films deposited on F-doped tin oxide (FTO) substrates (* denotes diffraction peaks from the FTO substrate). Fig. 2 Top (a) and cross-section (b) SEM images of R(301) thin film. Fig. 3 EBSD mapping obtained for R(301) thin film showing (a) pattern quality map, (b) phase mapping (red colour indicates the areas where rutile was indexed) and (c) orientation map showing the Inverse Pole Figures (IPF) with respect to Z axis, perpendicular to the sample substrate (IPF ‖ Z, colour key is shown in the inset of (c)). (d) Contoured IPF ‖ Z expressed in term of the multiple of uniform density (MUD). Fig. 4 HRTEM analysis of a lamellar specimen of R(301) thin film showing directional growth of preferentially orientated polycrystalline thin film on FTO substrate (a), micrograph obtained using EFTEM with the respective fringes (b) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED, c). The stereographic projection of the rutile form of TiO2 (d). Pictographic interpretation of the HRTEM observations shown in (e). Fig. 5 Raman spectra (a) taken for all the rutile TiO2 films made in this work and their respective Raman A1g and Eg intensity ratio (b). Fig. 6 Linear sweep voltammograms measured using a Xe lamp at 100 mW/cm2. The electrolyte consisted of 1.0 M NaOH. The right side corresponds to the LSV measured during ON/OFF conditions to depict both dark and illuminated contributions to the observed photocurrent. Fig. 7 (a) Open-circuit potential of rutile TiO2 electrodes in NaOH (1.0 M) with light off and light on. The n-type semiconductor’s conductivity was confirmed based on the photo-induced changes in voltage. (b) Nyquist plot at open-circuit voltage measured for the rutile TiO2 films made in this work. Fig. 8 Photoelectrochemical H2 evolution evaluated in regards of (a) evolved H2 produced during water splitting held at + 600 mV vs Ag/AgCl and Xe lamp illumination in NaOH 1.0 M. (b) shows the measured photocurrent during the photoelectrochemical catalysis and (c) depicts the Faradaic efficiency calculated from (a) and (b). Fig. 9 H2/O2 gas ratio measured for a R(301) sample during photoelectrochemical water splitting under illumination (100 mW/cm2) and a bias of + 600 mV vs Ag/AgCl (3.0 M). The numerical values indicate the ratio measured at each point. Fig. 10 Transmission Kikuchi Diffraction (TKD) map of a lamella specimen of a R(301) sample showing (a) quality map, (b) phase map with red colour representing indexation of rutile phase, (c) orientation map in the form of IPF ‖ Y showing twin boundaries with their misorientation profile showed in (d). Understanding the link between solid/liquid interfaces and photoelectrochemical activity in novel thin-film photoanodes of preferentially oriented high-index rutile TiO2 facets – A work inspired by Michel Che’s research on surface chemistry Alfonso Ballestas-Barrientos a Adrian T. Graphical abstract This work presents the first report of the deposition of a preferentially oriented film of rutile TiO2 exposing high-index facets. Control of the Cl–/F– mol ratio during the hydrolysis of TiCl4 enabled the deposition of different facets of rutile TiO2 on fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) substrates. When ranking films of varying facet composition and orientation, the high-index faceted film was found to have a higher activity photoelectrochemical activity towards water oxidation in spite of its low surface energy, as determined by Raman spectroscopy. Complementary photoelectrochemical studies and electron microscopy revealed the higher activity to originate from both the interaction at the electrode/electrolyte interface and the presence of active sites such as coincidence lattice sites in twin boundaries. This work, inspired by the research legacy of Michel Che, highlights the importance of surface chemistry and the presence of active sites in catalytic materials and showcases the coupling of different characterisation techniques to elucidate the mechanism governing the photoelectrochemical behaviour of supported metal oxides. Keywords Titanium dioxide Water splitting Crystal facet Grain boundaries 1 Introduction The development of highly active materials for harnessing solar energy is a crucial activity that is necessary to meet society’s increasing energy demands, while minimising environmental impact [1–4]. Metal oxide semiconductors, well-known as photoactive materials, can be tailored to improve their energy harnessing capabilities for photovoltaics, photocatalysis and energy storage devices [1,2]. In addition to controlling the phase composition and optical properties, engineering of crystals with controlled facets and defect composition has led to more active catalytic materials. In addition to the effect of the surface energy in faceted crystals, the catalyst/substrate interface must be considered as this further dictates the substrate adsorption/activation and the final desorption of products. Likewise, the band structure, charge separation and diffusion length in photoactive catalysts are relevant in their performance [5–8]. Therefore, understanding the chemistry of metal oxide surfaces is crucial in the exploration of ever more effective new materials that can absorb light and produce usable charge carriers [9–13]. The work of Prof. Michel Che was widely influential for our understanding of the importance of surface chemistry and active sites in heterogeneous catalysts [14–16]. To investigate the properties of catalytic systems at the surface level, Prof. Che used EPR, either solely, or in conjunction with other techniques, giving special attention to oxide supported catalysts and transition metal ions. From the study of the catalyst preparation, to the characterisation of active sites and mechanistic parameters, Prof. Che developed crucial insights regarding the elementary processes at the solid/fluid (liquid or gas) interface and built bridges between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis [14]. In particular, he investigated the chemical processes at the surfaces of different metal oxides, with TiO2 already receiving significant attention in his doctoral studies [16,17]. His pioneering studies of catalyst surfaces laid the groundwork for many of the current breakthroughs in facet engineering of different metal oxides, especially of TiO2. The potential benefits of TiO2 in a vast range of relevant applications including environment, energy and health make it a key compound and its optimisation through facet engineering has led to innumerable research studies that have yield powerful insights and technical applications [18]. Since 2008, with the ground-breaking study made by Yang et al., the synthesis of faceted crystals with high surface energy emerged with applications in catalysis and energy conversion [10]. Micrometre crystals of anatase TiO2 with a high percentage of {001} facets were synthesised using F– as capping agent [10]. The application of this synthetic direction has also been applied during the direct growth of crystals on substrates. In this scenario, different capping agents have been used to direct the preferential growth of TiO2 crystals, exposing well-defined facets on transparent conductive oxides (TCO) that have been used successfully as electrode materials [18,19] Recent reports by Butburee et al. compare different anatase TiO2 facets and found that the presence of oxidative/reductive active sites on the different anatase facets dictates the efficiencies for water oxidation and carbon dioxide reduction reactions [20]. In spite of the recent advances regarding the synthesis of TiO2 crystals with high surface energy, there are numerous contradictory results with respect to the order of reactivity of TiO2 low-index facets and high-index facets. It has been established previously that high-index facets, with a high density of undercoordinated atoms, are more energetic than the low-index facets [21–30]. However, an increasingly large number of studies have reported low-index facets of anatase TiO2 (including the {001}, {110} and {111} facets) with higher surface energetics than some of the high-index facets of TiO2 [7,31–33]. More surprisingly, studies on high-index facets of anatase TiO2 have shown lower chemical activity than reported for low-index facets [7–9,34–39]. Many of these reports are principally focussed on the surface energy of the predominant facet and dwell neither on the interaction of a substrate with that interface, nor on any potential synergistic effects between co-existing facets and/or the presence of twin crystals boundaries [40–43]. However, such important surface-related parameters must also be considered to get an in-depth understanding of the role of low- and high-index facets of anatase TiO2. To the best of our knowledge, there have been no reports of this type regarding the rutile phase thus far, a circumstance mainly attributed to synthetic difficulties and the unavailability of rutile TiO2 capping agents [18]. A fair comparison of different rutile TiO2 films must ensure that the photoactivity is mainly dictated by the actually exposed facets and not the nature of the capping agents and other additives used in their preparation. Previous comparative studies on the photoactivity of rutile TiO2 are based on commercial single crystal wafers. Whereas, in this work we present the hydrothermal growth of differently faceted rutile TiO2 films and compare their photoelectrochemical reactivity during water oxidation. Inspired by the legacy of Prof. Michel Che, we analysed differences in the photoreactivity measured considering the solid/liquid (electrolyte) interaction and the presence of active sites such as grain boundaries. Finally, the complementary use of different techniques to characterise these films allowed us to correlate the surface energy of the rutile TiO2 films with the observed photoelectrochemical activity towards hydrogen evolution. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reagents and materials TEC15 Fluorine doped tin oxide (FTO, 15 Ω/sq) substrates (Greatcell Energy Limited) were ultrasonically cleaned in successive baths of deionized water, acetone, and 2-propanol for 60 min. Hydrochloric acid (32% by weight, Merck), sodium fluoride (ACS grade, Merck) and sodium hydroxide (97%, Ajax Finechem) were used as received. Titanium tetrachloride (Puris grade, Sigma-Aldrich) was distilled and kept under N2 prior use. 2.2 Preparation of Ti precursor solution A 0.015 M TiCl4 solution was prepared by dissolving 826.3 μL of TiCl4 in 0.5 L of 3.5 M aqueous HCl kept at a temperature below 10 ⁰C using an ice-salt bath. 2.3 Hydrothermal deposition of rutile TiO2 films For the epitaxial growth of rutile TiO2 films, 30 mL of the Ti precursor solution was stirred and NaF was added to reach different Ti/F ratios (The composition of the different reaction mixtures is shown in Table S1). The solution was then stirred for 10 min and subsequently separated into 3 × 10 mL solutions and each one was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. A piece of FTO substrate was placed at an angle of 45⁰ against the wall of the Teflon-liner with the conducting side facing down and the autoclaved was then sealed. The hydrothermal synthesis was performed in air at 170 ⁰C for 12 h in an electric oven. After synthesis, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature under flowing air. The FTO substrate was then removed, rinsed extensively with deionized water and allowed to dry in ambient air. All the samples were defluorinated by thermal heating at 600 ⁰C for 90 min with a ramping rate of 5 ⁰C min−1 under static air. 2.4 Sample characterisation The crystal structure of the as-prepared films was examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical X'Pert PRO MPD) using Cu Kα (λ = 1.5419 Å) as the irradiation source. A Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM, Zeiss ULTRA plus) was used in this work to study the morphology and the crystal orientation using electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) and transmission Kikuchi diffraction (TKD). EBSD and TKD information were obtained using an Oxford Instruments AZtec v3.0 integrated EBSD, equipped with a Nordlys Nano EBSD detector and an X-Max20 silicon drift EDS detector. HRTEM and SAED were performed using a JEOL JEM-2200FS electron microscope with a 200 kV field emission gun and a Gatan Rio16 complementary metal-oxide semiconductor (CMOS) 4 k camera. Zero-loss energy filtering TEM (EFTEM) was applied using energy entrance aperture of 10 eV to obtain electron micrographs and diffraction patterns with less inelastic electrons. A lamella specimen was prepared for the TKD and HRTEM analysis using a Helios Hydra DualBeam Plasma FIB. The lamella sample was coated with a 20 nm of gold (Au) to prevent charging prior to FIB and finally welded to a molybdenum grid using xenon beam platinum welding. A Renishaw InVia Reflex System was used to study the Raman absorption of the films using a power of 50 mW and an excitation wavelength of 488 nm. 2.5 Photoelectrochemical performance measurements of rutile TiO2 films all photoelectrochemical (PEC) measurements were carried out at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 using a Xenon lamp (Solar Light Co., XPS 400) with an irradiance of 100 mW cm−2. The power for the illumination source was checked using a photometer (Solar Light Co., PMA2100) connected to a calibrated pyranometer (Solar Light Co., PMA 2144). For the data collection, BioLogic SP300 potentiostat with a standard three electrode configuration using platinum mesh, Ag/AgCl (3 M) (BASi instruments, MF-2052) and the as-prepared samples as the counter, reference and working electrode, respectively. 1 M NaOH was used as the electrolyte. The frequency range used for the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements, was from 200 kHz to 10 mHz and the sinusoidal potential perturbation was 50 mV. All the photoelectrochemical data was then analysed using the software package EC-Lab® V11.32. 2.6 Gas evolution measurements A flowing photoelectrochemical cell equipped with 3 compartments was used for gas evolution measurements using the same counter, reference and working electrodes as described above. During testing, the PEC filled with 1 M NaOH was purged with flowing He for one hour with continuous stirring and at a constant temperature of 20 ⁰C. H2 and O2 were carried at a flow rate of 30 mL/min into a GC (Shimadzu GC-2014, sample loop 1 mL) equipped with a pulsed discharge ionization detector (Vici PDID D-4-I-SH14-R; detection limit in the low ppb range). A constant potential of +0.6 V vs Ag/AgCl was held for two hours and gas samples were injected every 20 min, the measured current was used in combination with the gas measurement results to further determine the Faradaic efficiency of the photoelectrolysis. 3 Results and discussion In this work we have grown rutile TiO2 films epitaxially and with exposed high-index facets by adjusting the Cl–/F– ratio during the hydrothermal synthesis. The epitaxial growth of the films was promoted by the very small lattice mismatch between the FTO and the rutile TiO2 films [44–46]. Although multiple attempts have been reported to synthesise powder samples with these crystallographic features [18,47,48], as a first, we have developed a simple route to control the crystal orientation of rutile TiO2 films on FTO substrates, allowing us to compare their relative photoelectrochemical activity for water splitting and how it is related to the facets exposed. The epitaxial growth of rutile TiO2 was confirmed using XRD (Fig. 1 ). Different F–/Cl– ratios resulted in the growth of rutile TiO2 (SG, P42/mnm; JCPDS no. 88–1175, a = b = 0.4517 nm and c = 0.2940 nm) [44] with one enhanced peak corresponding to the (002), (101), (200) and (301) reflection planes. The absence of other diffraction peaks corresponding to TiO2 signifies the predominant orientation of crystals with specific planes parallel to the substrate. The formation of rutile TiO2 was possible despite the high concentrations of F– due to the high concomitant concentrations of Cl–. It is well-known that Cl– favours the formation of rutile over that of other phases [18,20]. Similar results were found in our previous studies in which, by employing only low concentrations of F– in the reaction medium, it was possible to co-deposit high index facets of anatase and rutile TiO2 on FTO substrates [49]. Although the synthesis of [001], [101] and [100] -oriented rutile TiO2 films have been previously demonstrated on FTO substrate [44,49,50], the new hydrothermal route developed in this work allowed high purity and high index rutile facets to be formed and stabilised without inducing the formation of the analogue anatase phase. In addition, by utilising the same reaction route and reaction components, a truly representative comparison of photoelectrochemical activities for rutile TiO2 facets of varying indices is possible, without the influence of other factors stemming from different synthetic pathways and directing agents. The morphology of the rutile TiO2 film was imaged by top-down surface and cross-section micrographs using scanning electron microscopy (Fig. 2 ). The uniform growth of TiO2 yielded a polycrystalline thin film of tetragonal prism-like crystals, directly attached to the FTO substrate. The film’s surface morphology is defined by crystal structures with clearly defined facets and vertices. The porosity observed in Fig. 2 was attributed to the detachment of fluorine during thermal treatment, which has been observed in previous studies [49,51]. The micrograph taken for the low-index faceted rutile TiO2 films show similar preferential alignment with the [100], [101] and [001] crystal growth perpendicular to the substrate (Figures S1–S3). The phase composition and crystallographic orientation was studied using EBSD and further corroborated with HRTEM. The EBSD phase map confirmed the formation of a tetragonal rutile phase (Fig. 3 b). Importantly, the anatase analogue of TiO2 was not detected in any of the samples. EBSD analysis confirmed the preferential alignment of the polycrystalline thin films as shown in the orientation map obtained from the inverse pole figures parallel to the substrate normal (IPF ‖ Z, Fig. 3c). The contoured inverse pole figure (Fig. 3d) shows the distribution of data points and confirms the highly texturized nature of the film, centred around the (201) crystal orientation. Similar results were also obtained for the low index facet thin films grown using lower Cl–/F– ratios (Figure S1–S3). The crystal growth orientation was further investigated using HRTEM on a lamella specimen taken using a FIB generated lift-out (Fig. 4 ). The perpendicular arrow in Fig. 4a was used as a planar trace to determine the crystal growth orientation with respect to the substrate. The electron diffraction pattern in Fig. 4c showcases the [201] crystal growth direction to be perpendicular to the substrate being parallel to the (501)* plane normal. To fully support these findings, we constructed the stereographic projection of rutile TiO2 (Fig. 4d) with the pole centre hkl = 001 and compared it to the contoured inverse pole figure shown in Fig. 3d. The information shown in Fig. 4d shows a very small discrepancy (less than 10 degrees) of the [201] growth direction with respect to the (301)* plane normal. A pictorial description of these findings is shown in Fig. 4e. Raman spectra of all the films (Fig. 5 ) confirmed the predominance of the rutile TiO2 phase over the analogue anatase phase, even after calcination, with the detection of the vibrational modes B1g, Eg and A1g as well as multiphoton processes [52]. Ab initio calculations by Ramamoorthy et al. [11] on the surface energies of different facets of rutile TiO2 surfaces indicate that (110) and (100) facets contain a mixture of penta- and hexa-coordinated surface Ti atoms with corresponding lower surface energies. These calculations also revealed the highest surface energies for the (101) and (001) surfaces, the latter one formed by tetra-coordinated Ti atoms, which makes these surfaces very unstable [11]. From the information obtained by us using Raman spectroscopy, the intensity ratio between the Eg and A1g Raman peaks were used to compare the surface energy of the different films according to the model described by Tian et al. [53] Thus, the Eg peak is produced by symmetric stretching vibrations of the OTiO bonds in TiO2, which is usually observed in facets with predominantly saturated 6c-Ti and 3c-O modes. In contrast, the A1g peak is mainly caused by antisymmetric bending vibrations and is caused by unsaturated 5c-Ti and 2c-O modes. Based on this, facets with higher surface energy will mainly contain unsaturated 5c-Ti and 2c-O modes and an increased intensity in the A1g Raman peak, while low energy facets will show a decreased intensity in the A1g Raman peak but an enhanced intensity on the Eg signal [13,53]. Fig. 5 shows that the surface energy of the novel (301) faceted rutile TiO2 films is lower than that of the films with (101) and (002) facets, but with a slightly higher surface energy than the (200) rutile TiO2 facet. The initial findings made by Ramamoorthy’s work agrees well with the results shown in Fig. 5 and indicate that the R(301) film is mainly constituted by a mixture of 5c-Ti and 3c-O atoms with relatively lower surface energy compared to the corresponding (101) and (001) surfaces. Different TiO2 surfaces and their surface atomic composition are an important determinant for in the photocatalytic activity of TiO2. The ground-breaking work of Tsujiko et al. [54] demonstrated the role of different rutile TiO2 surfaces on the photostability and photo-activity characteristics of this phase of TiO2 during water oxidation. Moreover, based on these results, Salvador [55] proposed a redox photooxidation mechanism to interpret experimental observations on the stability and activity of different surface atomic arrangement of TiO2 surfaces. This mechanism involves the initial photo-induced generation of bridging oxygen/hydroxyl species on the surface from adsorbed water molecules at bridging oxygen vacancies. In addition, this model explained that TiO2 surfaces with unsaturated Ti (4c-Ti and 5c-Ti) atoms are more photoreactive, however, they are less stable and undergo photoetching at higher rates than low energy facets. 3.1 Photoelectrochemical activity of rutile TiO2 films The versatility of our synthetic route to the controlled preparation of preferentially oriented films of rutile TiO2 films becomes crucial in the determination of the relative differences in photoelectrochemical (PEC) activity between films of different orientation and index values. In this regard, the impact of other variables such as capping agent nature, temperature and surface composition can be neglected as all the films were synthesised under the same synthetic route, with the only variation being the composition of the reaction mixture. Furthermore, to eliminate the influence of fluoride on the PEC activity, the samples were treated thermally to improve the contact between the TiO2 film and the substrate as well as to eliminate the presence of fluoride on the surface. The photocurrent was measured in a manner that also determined the contribution from any pure electrochemical effect by performing the same test under on-off (Fig. 6 ) and dark conditions. The shape of the photocurrent-voltage curves is representative of an n-type TiO2 with the initial current being limited by the intrinsic resistance of the rutile TiO2 film and reaching a maximum photocurrent at higher potentials due to interfacial limitations on the semiconductor/electrolyte interface[56–58]. The current measured under on/off conditions confirmed negligible contribution from dark current on the potential range of study. Based on the photocurrent measured, the order of reactivity for the films made in this work were R(301) > R(200) > R(002) > R(101), which is in the reverse order to the surface energy based on the A1g/Eg Raman intensity ratio, i.e. lower surface energy leads to higher PEC. To evaluate the interactions between the rutile TiO2 film with the electrolyte further, open-circuit voltage and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurements were performed (Fig. 7 ). The open-circuit potential was used to compare the driving force for water splitting with different rutile films. The magnitude of the electric field generated at the semiconductor/electrolyte interface upon illumination is limited by the separation of the quasi-Fermi levels (EqF,e- and EqF,h+). As shown on the inset of Fig. 7a, lowering the position of the holes’ quasi-Fermi level (EqF,h+) results in larger photovoltage values and better alignment of the bands towards water oxidation [59,60]. As depicted in Fig. 7, the photo-generated voltage was higher for the films with lower surface energy. Differences in the photovoltage values are due to losses including non-radiative recombination, spontaneous emission and incomplete light trapping [60]. In addition to thermodynamic forces being able to impact the photooxidative properties of the films, the transfer of holes across the semiconductor/electrolyte interface also plays a key role. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was used to analyse the charge transfer properties for the different films at this interface. Fig. 7b shows depressed semi-circles for all the rutile TiO2, as compared to single crystal data, which indicates the presence surface heterogeneities including grain boundaries or other variations in surface properties of the electrode [61]. The radius of the half-circle represents the resistance of the charge transfer on the electrode/electrolyte interface [61,62]. Accordingly, a smaller radius was observed for films of lower surface energy, indicating a faster interfacial charge transfer and less accumulation of charge carriers on the surface. The imperfections, in effect, provide a means for the surface to relax and reduce its energy. The faster charge transfer also translates into lower probabilities of electron-hole recombination. The charge transfer resistance follows the sequence of R(301) < R(002) < R(200) < R(101), which at steady state is a perfect match to the photoelectrochemical activity trends shown in Fig. 6. The activity of these films was then compared for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) under both illumination (100 mW/cm2) and applied bias (Fig. 8 ). The amount of hydrogen evolved using the newly synthesised R(301) sample was considerable higher than that observed for the other rutile TiO2 films (Fig. 8a). Surprisingly, the R(301) sample had a much higher efficiency than the R(200) film in spite of their similar activities as shown in Fig. 6. In addition, the measured photocurrent (Fig. 8b) allowed calculations of the Faradaic efficiencies (FE, Fig. 8c): F E % = V H 2 , m V H 2 , I × 100 where V H 2 , m corresponds to the amount of H2 measured by gas chromatography (Figure S4) and V H 2 , I is the volume of H2 calculated from the total current passed through during the hydrogen evolution experiments using the Faradaic Law: V H 2 , I = I ( A ) × t ( s ) × V m ( L / m o l ) F C / m o l × z , in which I × t corresponds to the total capacity, C, which is derived from the integration of the current intensity vs time in Fig. 8b, F is the Faradaic constant, Vm is the molar volume at STP (Vm = 24 L/mol) and z = 2, corresponding to the number of electrons transferred per mol of hydrogen evolved. To corroborate that the gas evolved originated from true water splitting, the H2:O2 molar ratio was measured (Fig. 9 ). While the initial ratio was higher due to the higher solubility of oxygen in water, at steady state with an oxygen-saturated solution on both sides of the cell, the gas ratio stabilises to 2.28. This slight deviation from the ideal ratio of 2 can be rationalised, e.g. by a small contribution to the current intensity from undesired side reactions, including photo-corrosion of the electrodes. The results shown in Fig. 8 and Fig. 9 confirm that the novel high-index facets rutile TiO2 films are substantially more photoreactive than the films with low-index facets. A number of activity comparisons of single crystal rutile TiO2, using commercial wafers followed by polishing/etching to expose specific facets, have been published. Lowekamp et al. studied the activity of different rutile TiO2 facets during photoreduction of Ag+ to Ag [63]. A further comparison of the photocatalytic activity of different single crystal rutile TiO2 facets was developed by Ikuma et al. providing insights on the role of surface oxygen (Os) on the decomposition of fatty acids [12,64,65]. These single crystal wafers studies show that the (001) rutile facet is more active, which is as predicted by the Wulff construction and surface energies calculated in vacuum [11,12,63–65]. However, in this work we compare rutile TiO2 films consisting of an evenly coated surface made of preferentially oriented crystallites with lateral grain boundaries and we observe that facets with lower surface energy resulted in higher photoreactivity in water oxidation. Moreover, our photoelectrochemical results revealed that the semiconductor/electrolyte interface plays a key role in the charge carrier separation and concomitant photoelectrochemical activity. It is noteworthy that this type of contradiction has been found in anatase TiO2 facets: Pan et al., studied clean facets of anatase TiO2 and found the photoactivity order for OH radicals and hydrogen evolution to be {010} > {101} > {001}, which is different to that reported in the established literature, where the photoactivity of {001} is greater than the {101} and {010} [9]. These reports and the photoelectrochemical studies presented in this work clearly demonstrate that surface energy is not the only factor determining the performance of TiO2 crystals in both their anatase and rutile forms [6,7,9]. Instead, the cooperative effect of the surface atomic coordination, the band structure and interaction at the semiconductor/electrolyte interface determine much of the observed photoreactivity in faceted TiO2 crystals. To further understand the mechanism for the greater photoreactivity of the highly reactive facet of rutile TiO2, SEM transmission Kikuchi diffraction (TKD) analysis using EBSD detector was performed on a lamella specimen. In this scenario, the IPF ‖ Z map shown in Fig. 3 is equivalent to the IPF ‖ Y orientation map in the TKD analysis (Fig. 10 c). The TKD results were consistent with the EBSD analysis and made it possible to detect internal grain boundary defects. Fig. 10 shows both the (101) and the uncommon (301) twin boundaries, depicted by their corresponding misorientation angles. A more detailed look at the EBSD data also confirmed the presence of these twin defects on the surface of the film (Fig. 11 ). It is noteworthy that this type of grain boundary was not observed in the other thin films with low-index facets, which would be consistent with these twin boundaries positively impacting the photoelectrochemical activity of our films (Fig. 12 ). As depicted in Fig. 12, all the samples with lower photoelectrochemical activity were highly aligned with very small misorientation angles. On the contrary, most of the grains in the newly made rutile TiO2 film presented a misorientation angle corresponding to the (101) twin boundaries. The growth pattern as revealed in Figs. 10–12 is strong evidence for the impact of twin boundaries, in addition to the solid/liquid interface, on the photoelectrochemical activity of the films studied in this work. The role of grain boundaries has been the centre of attention in applications involving the separation of charge carriers [66–69]. Most of these studies have indicated that grain boundaries in rutile TiO2 can be engineered with the aim of improving charge carrier separation in photocatalytic and photovoltaic applications. Grain boundaries in polycrystalline TiO2 present unique properties including lower atomic coordination and an excess of free volume on the boundary generating electrical perturbations and a higher affinity for electrons. Accordingly, the combination of elemental doping on grain boundaries has also been suggested to modify and control the effect of defects during electron-hole separation [69]. In our previous work, we successfully introduced the interaction of plasmonic silver nanoparticles on polycrystalline rutile TiO2 films. An improved charge transfer between Ag NPs and the semiconductor was achieved by preferentially depositing silver nanoparticles on the grain boundaries, which resulted in higher visible-light driven water oxidation [70]. The effect of grain boundaries in the improvement of the lithium diffusion in lithium ion batteries has also been studied by us and others, confirming the remarkable property altering effects of these types of defects with respect to bulk materials [69,71]. In the present work, an additional effect is introduced by creating high density of twin boundaries in high-index rutile TiO2 films. A feature in this type of boundary is the formation of twin planes with a constant spacing and a long-range order, usually referred as coincidence site lattices (CSL) [72,73]. In comparison to the bulk and other general grain boundaries, the generation of CSL has remarkable effects on the optical and electronic properties of materials as their boundary energy is lower, while possessing a larger boundary free volume [74,75]. The particularity of this type of boundary is usually reflected on the charge mobility, resistivity and the ability to function as source or sink for vacancies. Recent reports also confirm the effectiveness of twin boundaries at separating charge carriers during hydrogen evolution [76]. Combined, the EBSD and TKD analysis explains the higher photoelectrochemical activity observed for high-index facets of rutile TiO2. The properties exhibited by the newly made film make it attractive for applications involving electron transport in photovoltaic material, with lead-halide perovskite solar cells being a target. Indeed, this work is currently on-going and it is expected that grain boundary engineering will contribute in the improvement of the interface between the perovskite layer and the electron transporting component. In summary, in this work high-index faceted rutile TiO2 films were designed and synthesised. The interfacial interaction at the TiO2/electrolyte interface was improved by the introduction of additional twin boundaries. Consequently, as compared to lower index films made using identical synthetic conditions and only adjusting the reaction medium composition, films with higher index facets, exhibited higher photoelectrochemical activity. This study reports the simple, controlled and high yield synthesis of high-index facets of metal oxides, their surface energy characterisation and their comparison with low-index facets. Interactions at the semiconductor/electrolyte interface are presented and interpreted via an in-depth characterisation of surface features (twin boundaries), which were found to be responsible for the high performance in water oxidation. Computational modelling to probe these phenomena further is being pursued. coredata.dc:description: This work presents the first report of the deposition of a preferentially oriented film of rutile TiO2 exposing high-index facets. Control of the Cl–/F– mol ratio during the hydrolysis of TiCl4 enabled the deposition of different facets of rutile TiO2 on fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) substrates. When ranking films of varying facet composition and orientation, the high-index faceted film was found to have a higher activity photoelectrochemical activity towards water oxidation in spite of its low surface energy, as determined by Raman spectroscopy. Complementary photoelectrochemical studies and electron microscopy revealed the higher activity to originate from both the interaction at the electrode/electrolyte interface and the presence of active sites such as coincidence lattice sites in twin boundaries. This work, inspired by the research legacy of Michel Che, highlights the importance of surface chemistry and the presence of active sites in catalytic materials and showcases the coupling of different characterisation techniques to elucidate the mechanism governing the photoelectrochemical behaviour of supported metal oxides.
coredata.dc:title: Understanding the link between solid/liquid interfaces and photoelectrochemical activity in novel thin-film photoanodes of preferentially oriented high-index rutile TiO2 facets – A work inspired by Michel Che’s research on surface chemistry
